Complexity of Deciding Detectability in Discrete Event Systems

Tom√°≈°¬†Masopust masopust@math.cas.cz Institute of Mathematics, Czech Academy of Sciences, ≈Ωi≈ækova 22, 616 62 Brno, Czechia
Abstract

Detectability of discrete event systems (DESs) is a question whether the current and subsequent states can be determined based on observations. Shu and Lin designed a polynomial-time algorithm to check strong (periodic) detectability and an exponential-time (polynomial-space) algorithm to check weak (periodic) detectability. Zhang showed that checking weak (periodic) detectability is PSpace-complete. This intractable complexity opens a question whether there are structurally simpler DESs for which the problem is tractable. In this paper, we show that it is not the case by considering DESs represented as deterministic finite automata without non-trivial cycles, which are structurally the simplest deadlock-free DESs. We show that even for such very simple DESs, checking weak (periodic) detectability remains intractable. On the contrary, we show that strong (periodic) detectability of DESs can be efficiently verified on a parallel computer.

keywords:
Discrete event systems; Finite automata; Detectability

1 Introduction

The detectability problem of discrete event systems (DESs) is a question whether the current and subsequent states of a DES can be determined based on observations. The problem was introduced and studied by Shu et al.¬†[11, 13]. Detectability generalizes other notions studied in the literature¬†[3, 10], such as stability of Ozveren and Willsky¬†[9]. Shu et al. further argue that many practical problems can be formulated as the detectability problem for DESs.

Four variants of detectability have been defined: strong and weak detectability and strong and weak periodic detectability¬†[13]. Shu et al.¬†[13] investigated detectability for deterministic DESs. A deterministic DES is modeled as a deterministic finite automaton with a set of initial states rather than a single initial state. The motivation for more initial states comes from the observation that it is often not known which state the system is initially in. They designed exponential algorithms to decide detectability of DESs based on the computation of the observer. Later, to be able to handle more problems, they extended their study to nondeterministic DESs and improved the algorithms for strong (periodic) detectability of nondeterministic DESs to polynomial time¬†[11]. Concerning the complexity of deciding weak detectability, Zhang¬†[16] showed that the problem is PSpace-complete and that PSpace-hardness holds even for deterministic DESs with all events observable. Shu and Lin¬†[12] further extended strong detectability to delayed DESs and developed a polynomial-time algorithm to check strong detectability for delayed DESs. Yin and Lafortune¬†[15] recently extended weak and strong detectability to modular DESs and showed that checking both strong modular detectability and weak modular detectability is PSpace-hard.

Zhang‚Äôs intractable complexity of deciding weak (periodic) detectability opens the question whether there are structurally simpler DESs for which tractability can be achieved. To tackle this question, we consider structurally the simplest deadlock-free DESs modeled as deterministic finite automata without non-trivial cycles, that is, every cycle is in the form of a self-loop in a state of the DES. We show that even for these very simple DESs, checking weak (periodic) detectability remains PSpace-complete, and hence the problem is intractable for all practical cases.

On the other hand, we show that deciding strong (periodic) detectability of DESs is NL-complete. Since NL is the class of problems that can be efficiently parallelized¬†[1], we obtain that strong (periodic) detectability can be efficiently verified on a parallel computer.

A discrete event system (DES) is modeled as an NFA Gùê∫G with all states marked. The detectability problems are based on the observation of events, described by the projection P:Œ£‚àó‚ÜíŒ£o‚àó:ùëÉ‚ÜísuperscriptŒ£superscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëúP\colon\Sigma^{*}\to\Sigma_{o}^{*}. The definition can readily be extended to infinite words and languages.

As usual when detectability is studied¬†[11], we make the following two assumptions on the DES G=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºG=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I):

    No loop in Gùê∫G consists solely of unobservable events: for every q‚ààQùëûùëÑq\in Q and every w‚ààŒ£u‚Äão+ùë§superscriptsubscriptŒ£ùë¢ùëúw\in\Sigma_{uo}^{+}, q‚àâŒ¥‚Äã(q,w)ùëûùõøùëûùë§q\notin\delta(q,w).

The set of infinite sequences of events generated by the DES Gùê∫G is denoted by Lœâ‚Äã(G)superscriptùêøùúîùê∫L^{\omega}(G). Given Q‚Ä≤‚äÜQsuperscriptùëÑ‚Ä≤ùëÑQ^{\prime}\subseteq Q, the set of all possible states after observing a word t‚ààŒ£o‚àóùë°superscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëút\in\Sigma_{o}^{*} is denoted by R‚Äã(Q‚Ä≤,t)=‚à™w‚ààŒ£‚àó,P‚Äã(w)=tŒ¥‚Äã(Q‚Ä≤,w)ùëÖsuperscriptùëÑ‚Ä≤ùë°subscriptformulae-sequenceùë§superscriptŒ£ùëÉùë§ùë°ùõøsuperscriptùëÑ‚Ä≤ùë§R(Q^{\prime},t)=\cup_{w\in\Sigma^{*},P(w)=t}\delta(Q^{\prime},w). For w‚ààLœâ‚Äã(G)ùë§superscriptùêøùúîùê∫w\in L^{\omega}(G), we denote the set of its prefixes by P‚Äãr‚Äã(w)ùëÉùëüùë§Pr(w).

A decision problem is a yes-no question, such as ‚ÄúIs an NFA Aùê¥A deterministic?‚Äù A decision problem is decidable if there exists an algorithm solving the problem. Complexity theory classifies decidable problems to classes based on the time or space an algorithm needs to solve the problem. The complexity classes we consider in this paper are NL, P, NP, and PSpace denoting the classes of problems solvable by a nondeterministic logarithmic-space, deterministic polynomial-time, nondeterministic polynomial-time, and deterministic polynomial-space algorithm, respectively. The hierarchy of classes is NL ‚äÜ\subseteq P ‚äÜ\subseteq NP ‚äÜ\subseteq PSpace. Which of the inclusions are strict is an open problem. The widely accepted conjecture is that all are strict. A decision problem is NL-complete (resp. NP-complete, PSpace-complete) if it belongs to NL (resp. NP, PSpace) and every problem from NL (resp. NP, PSpace) can be reduced to it by a deterministic logarithmic-space (resp. polynomial-time) algorithm.

3 The Detectability Problems

In this section, we recall the definitions of the detectability problems¬†[11]. Let Œ£Œ£\Sigma be an alphabet, Œ£o‚äÜŒ£subscriptŒ£ùëúŒ£\Sigma_{o}\subseteq\Sigma the set of observable events, and PùëÉP the projection from Œ£Œ£\Sigma to Œ£osubscriptŒ£ùëú\Sigma_{o}.

Definition 1 (Strong detectability).

A DES G=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºG=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I) is strongly detectable with respect to Œ£u‚ÄãosubscriptŒ£ùë¢ùëú\Sigma_{uo} if we can determine, after a finite number of observations, the current and subsequent states of the system for all trajectories of the system, i.e., (‚àÉn‚àà‚Ñï)‚Äã(‚àÄs‚ààLœâ‚Äã(G))‚Äã(‚àÄt‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s))‚Äã|P‚Äã(t)|>n‚áí|R‚Äã(I,P‚Äã(t))|=1ùëõ‚Ñïfor-allùë†superscriptùêøùúîùê∫for-allùë°ùëÉùëüùë†ùëÉùë°ùëõ‚áíùëÖùêºùëÉùë°1(\exists n\in\mathbb{N})(\forall s\in L^{\omega}(G))(\forall t\in Pr(s))|P(t)|>n\Rightarrow|R(I,P(t))|=1.

Definition 2 (Strong periodic detectability).

A DES G=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºG=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I) is strongly periodically detectable with respect to Œ£u‚ÄãosubscriptŒ£ùë¢ùëú\Sigma_{uo} if we can periodically determine the current state of the system for all trajectories of the system, i.e., (‚àÉn‚àà‚Ñï)‚Äã(‚àÄs‚ààLœâ‚Äã(G))‚Äã(‚àÄt‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s))‚Äã(‚àÉt‚Ä≤‚ààŒ£‚àó)‚Äãt‚Äãt‚Ä≤‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s)‚àß|P‚Äã(t‚Ä≤)|<n‚àß|R‚Äã(I,P‚Äã(t‚Äãt‚Ä≤))|=1ùëõ‚Ñïfor-allùë†superscriptùêøùúîùê∫for-allùë°ùëÉùëüùë†superscriptùë°‚Ä≤superscriptŒ£ùë°superscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùëÉùëüùë†ùëÉsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùëõùëÖùêºùëÉùë°superscriptùë°‚Ä≤1(\exists n\in\mathbb{N})(\forall s\in L^{\omega}(G))(\forall t\in Pr(s))(\exists t^{\prime}\in\Sigma^{*})tt^{\prime}\in Pr(s)\land|P(t^{\prime})|<n\land|R(I,P(tt^{\prime}))|=1.

Definition 3 (Weak detectability).

A DES G=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºG=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I) is weakly detectable with respect to Œ£u‚ÄãosubscriptŒ£ùë¢ùëú\Sigma_{uo} if we can determine, after a finite number of observations, the current and subsequent states of the system for some trajectories of the system, i.e., (‚àÉn‚àà‚Ñï)‚Äã(‚àÉs‚ààLœâ‚Äã(G))‚Äã(‚àÄt‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s))‚Äã|P‚Äã(t)|>n‚áí|R‚Äã(I,P‚Äã(t))|=1ùëõ‚Ñïùë†superscriptùêøùúîùê∫for-allùë°ùëÉùëüùë†ùëÉùë°ùëõ‚áíùëÖùêºùëÉùë°1(\exists n\in\mathbb{N})(\exists s\in L^{\omega}(G))(\forall t\in Pr(s))|P(t)|>n\Rightarrow|R(I,P(t))|=1.

Definition 4 (Weak periodic detectability).

A DES G=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºG=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I) is weakly periodically detectable with respect to Œ£u‚ÄãosubscriptŒ£ùë¢ùëú\Sigma_{uo} if we can periodically determine the current state of the system for some trajectories of the system, i.e., (‚àÉn‚àà‚Ñï)‚Äã(‚àÉs‚ààLœâ‚Äã(G))‚Äã(‚àÄt‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s))‚Äã(‚àÉt‚Ä≤‚ààŒ£‚àó)‚Äãt‚Äãt‚Ä≤‚ààP‚Äãr‚Äã(s)‚àß|P‚Äã(t‚Ä≤)|<n‚àß|R‚Äã(I,P‚Äã(t‚Äãt‚Ä≤))|=1ùëõ‚Ñïùë†superscriptùêøùúîùê∫for-allùë°ùëÉùëüùë†superscriptùë°‚Ä≤superscriptŒ£ùë°superscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùëÉùëüùë†ùëÉsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤ùëõùëÖùêºùëÉùë°superscriptùë°‚Ä≤1(\exists n\in\mathbb{N})(\exists s\in L^{\omega}(G))(\forall t\in Pr(s))(\exists t^{\prime}\in\Sigma^{*})tt^{\prime}\in Pr(s)\land|P(t^{\prime})|<n\land|R(I,P(tt^{\prime}))|=1.

In what follows, we make often implicit use of the following lemma whose proof is obvious by definition.

4 Complexity of Deciding Weak Detectability

To decide weak (periodic) detectability of a DES, Shu and Lin¬†[11] construct the observer and prove that the DES is weakly detectable if and only if there is a reachable cycle in the observer consisting of singleton DES state sets, and that the DES is weakly periodically detectable if and only if there is a reachable cycle in the observer containing a singleton DES state set. Because of the construction of the observer, the algorithms are exponential. However, as pointed out by Zhang¬†[16], the algorithms require only polynomial space.

Zhang¬†[16] further shows that deciding weak (periodic) detectability is PSpace-hard. His construction results in a deterministic DES with several initial states. Although the transitions are deterministic, the DES is not a DFA because of the non-unique initial state. We slightly improve Zhang‚Äôs result.

Theorem 6.

Deciding whether a deterministic DES over a binary alphabet is weakly (periodically) detectable is PSpace-complete.

Proof 4.1.

Membership in PSpace is known¬†[16]. To show hardness, we modify Zhang‚Äôs construction reducing the finite automata intersection problem: given a sequence of total111In his construction, Zhang does not assume that Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} are total, which makes his construction incorrect. The assumption that Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} are total fixes this minor mistake. DFAs A1,‚Ä¶,Ansubscriptùê¥1‚Ä¶subscriptùê¥ùëõA_{1},\ldots,A_{n} over a common alphabet Œ£Œ£\Sigma, the problem asks whether ‚à©i=1nL‚Äã(Ai)‚â†‚àÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëñ\cap_{i=1}^{n}L(A_{i})\neq\emptyset. Without loss of generality, we may assume that Œ£={0,1}Œ£01\Sigma=\{0,1\}¬†[6].

In every Ai=(Qi,{0,1},Œ¥i,q0i,Fi)subscriptùê¥ùëñsubscriptùëÑùëñ01subscriptùõøùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëñsubscriptùêπùëñA_{i}=(Q_{i},\{0,1\},\delta_{i},q_{0}^{i},F_{i}), we replace every transition (p,x,q)ùëùùë•ùëû(p,x,q) by two transitions (p,0,p‚Ä≤)ùëù0superscriptùëù‚Ä≤(p,0,p^{\prime}) and (p‚Ä≤,x,q)superscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùë•ùëû(p^{\prime},x,q). Intuitively, we encode 00 as 000000 and 111 as 010101. Let Ai‚Ä≤=(Qi‚à™Qi‚Ä≤,{0,1},Œ¥i‚Ä≤,q0i,Fi)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÑùëñ‚Ä≤01superscriptsubscriptùõøùëñ‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëû0ùëñsubscriptùêπùëñA_{i}^{\prime}=(Q_{i}\cup Q_{i}^{\prime},\{0,1\},\delta_{i}^{\prime},q_{0}^{i},F_{i}) denote the resulting DFA, where Qi‚Ä≤={p‚Ä≤‚à£p‚ààQi}superscriptsubscriptùëÑùëñ‚Ä≤conditional-setsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùëùsubscriptùëÑùëñQ_{i}^{\prime}=\{p^{\prime}\mid p\in Q_{i}\}. Corollary 7.

Deciding whether a DES modeled as a DFA is weakly (periodically) detectable is PSpace-complete even if the DES has only three events, one of which is unobservable.

Proof 4.2.

Consider the deterministic DES Gùê∫G constructed in the proof of Theorem¬†6 with n+1ùëõ1n+1 initial states denoted by q1,‚Ä¶,qn+1subscriptùëû1‚Ä¶subscriptùëûùëõ1q_{1},\ldots,q_{n+1}. We construct G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} from Gùê∫G by adding a new unobservable event aùëéa, the transitions (qi,a,qi+1)subscriptùëûùëñùëésubscriptùëûùëñ1(q_{i},a,q_{i+1}), for i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, and by setting q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} to be the sole initial state of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}. All other transitions of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} coincide with those of Gùê∫G. Then G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is a DFA and it is easy to see that the observers of Gùê∫G with respect to ‚àÖ\emptyset and of G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with respect to {a}ùëé\{a\} are identical, and hence Gùê∫G is weakly (periodically) detectable if and only if G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} is.

The unobservable event in the corollary is unavoidable because any DES modeled as a DFA with all events observable is always in a unique state, and hence trivially detectable. We now show that two observable events are also necessary for PSpace-hardness.

Theorem 8.

Deciding whether a DES over a unary alphabet is weakly detectable is in P, and whether it is weakly periodically detectable is in NP.

Proof 4.3.

Let G=(Q,{a},Œ¥,I)ùê∫ùëÑùëéùõøùêºG=(Q,\{a\},\delta,I) be a DES with nùëõn states. Then the observer of Gùê∫G consists of a sequence of kùëòk states followed by a cycle consisting of ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell states, that is, the language of Gùê∫G is ak‚Äã(a‚Ñì)‚àósuperscriptùëéùëòsuperscriptsuperscriptùëé‚Ñìa^{k}(a^{\ell})^{*}. Since the number of states of the observer of Gùê∫G is at most 2nsuperscript2ùëõ2^{n}, k+‚Ñì‚â§2nùëò‚Ñìsuperscript2ùëõk+\ell\leq 2^{n}.

Now, Gùê∫G is weakly detectable if and only if the states of the cycle of the observer of Gùê∫G consist only of singleton states of Gùê∫G, that is, |Œ¥‚Äã(I,ak+i)|=1ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëéùëòùëñ1|\delta(I,a^{k+i})|=1 for i=0,‚Ä¶,‚Ñìùëñ0‚Ä¶‚Ñìi=0,\ldots,\ell and ‚Ñì‚â§n‚Ñìùëõ\ell\leq n, since the observer of Gùê∫G has at most nùëõn singleton sets. Since Œ¥‚Äã(I,ak+i)ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëéùëòùëñ\delta(I,a^{k+i}), for i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, can be computed in polynomial time using the fast matrix multiplication, cf. Masopust¬†[8] for more details and an example, we can decide weak detectability in polynomial time. Namely, we compute Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+i)ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëñ\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+i}), for i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, check that |Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+i)|=1ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëñ1|\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+i})|=1 and that there are i<jùëñùëói<j such that Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+i)=Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+j)ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëñùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëó\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+i})=\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+j}).

Similarly, Gùê∫G is weakly periodically detectable if and only if there is m‚â§2nùëösuperscript2ùëõm\leq 2^{n} such that |Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+m)|=1ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëö1|\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+m})|=1. An NP algorithm can guess mùëöm in binary and verify the guess in polynomial time by computing Œ¥‚Äã(I,a2n+m)ùõøùêºsuperscriptùëésuperscript2ùëõùëö\delta(I,a^{2^{n}+m}) using the fast matrix multiplication.

4.1 Simplest DESs

Zhang‚Äôs result gives rise to a question whether there are structurally simpler DESs with a tractable complexity of weak (periodic) detectability. The simplest DESs are acyclic DFAs, recognizing finite languages. Acyclic DESs are not deadlock-free. To fulfill deadlock-freeness, we consider DESs modeled as DFAs with cycles only in the form of self-loops. Such DFAs recognize a strict subclass of regular languages strictly included in star-free languages¬†[2]. Star-free languages are languages definable by linear temporal logic widely used as a specification language in automated verification.

Let A=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I,F)ùê¥ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºùêπA=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I,F) be an NFA. The reachability relation ‚â§\leq on the state set QùëÑQ is defined by p‚â§qùëùùëûp\leq q if there is w‚ààŒ£‚àóùë§superscriptŒ£w\in\Sigma^{*} such that q‚ààŒ¥‚Äã(p,w)ùëûùõøùëùùë§q\in\delta(p,w). The NFA Aùê¥A is partially ordered (poNFA) if the reachability relation ‚â§\leq is a partial order. If Aùê¥A is a DFA, we use the notation poDFA.

A restricted partially ordered NFA (rpoNFA) is a poNFA that is self-loop deterministic in the sense that the pattern of Fig.¬†2 does not appear. Formally, for every state qùëûq and every event aùëéa, if q‚ààŒ¥‚Äã(q,a)ùëûùõøùëûùëéq\in\delta(q,a) then Œ¥‚Äã(q,a)={q}ùõøùëûùëéùëû\delta(q,a)=\{q\}.

This condition is trivially satisfied by poDFAs and it is known that poDFAs and rpoNFAs recognize the same class of languages¬†[7].

We show that deciding weak (periodic) detectability remains PSpace-complete even if the DES is modeled as a poDFA, or as an rpoNFA with all events observable. Consequently, the problem is intractable for all practical cases.

Recall that Zhang¬†[16] obtained his result by reducing the finite automata intersection problem. Since his construction does not introduce any non-trivial cycles, it could seem that it also shows the result for poDFAs. This is, however, not the case because the complexity of the intersection problem for poDFAs is not known. Therefore, to prove our results, we need to use a different technique, namely the universality problem for rpoNFAs. The problem asks, given an rpoNFA Aùê¥A over Œ£Œ£\Sigma, whether L‚Äã(A)=Œ£‚àóùêøùê¥superscriptŒ£L(A)=\Sigma^{*}. It is PSpace-complete in general and coNP-complete if the alphabet is fixed a priori¬†[7].

Theorem 9.

Deciding weak (periodic) detectability of DESs modeled as rpoNFAs is PSpace-complete even if all events are observable.

Proof 4.4.

Membership in PSpace holds for general NFAs¬†[16]. To show hardness, we reduce the non-universality problem for rpoNFAs. Let A=(Q,Œ£,Œ¥,I,F)ùê¥ùëÑŒ£ùõøùêºùêπA=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I,F) be an rpoNFA. We construct an rpoNFA A‚Ä≤=(Q‚à™{‚ô£,‚ãÜ},Œ£‚à™{‚ãÑ},Œ¥‚Ä≤,I‚à™{‚ô£},F)superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùëÑ‚ô£‚ãÜŒ£‚ãÑsuperscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùêº‚ô£ùêπA^{\prime}=(Q\cup\{\clubsuit,\star\},\Sigma\cup\{\diamond\},\delta^{\prime},I\cup\{\clubsuit\},F), where ‚ô£‚ô£\clubsuit and ‚ãÜ‚ãÜ\star are new states and ‚ãÑ‚ãÑ\diamond is a new event. Let Œ¥‚Ä≤=Œ¥superscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùõø\delta^{\prime}=\delta. We extended Œ¥‚Ä≤superscriptùõø‚Ä≤\delta^{\prime} as follows. For every non-marked state pùëùp of Aùê¥A, we add the transition (p,‚ãÑ,‚ô£)ùëù‚ãÑ‚ô£(p,\diamond,\clubsuit) to Œ¥‚Ä≤superscriptùõø‚Ä≤\delta^{\prime}, and for every marked state pùëùp of Aùê¥A, we add the transition (p,‚ãÑ,‚ãÜ)ùëù‚ãÑ‚ãÜ(p,\diamond,\star) to Œ¥‚Ä≤superscriptùõø‚Ä≤\delta^{\prime}. We add transitions (‚ô£,a,‚ô£)‚ô£ùëé‚ô£(\clubsuit,a,\clubsuit) and (‚ãÜ,a,‚ãÜ)‚ãÜùëé‚ãÜ(\star,a,\star) to Œ¥‚Ä≤superscriptùõø‚Ä≤\delta^{\prime} for every event aùëéa of A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime}. The construction is illustrated in Fig.¬†3. All events are observable. We show that Aùê¥A is non-universal if and only if A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} is weakly (periodically) detectable.

If Aùê¥A is not universal, there is a word w‚ààŒ£‚àó‚àñL‚Äã(A)ùë§superscriptŒ£ùêøùê¥w\in\Sigma^{*}\setminus L(A) and Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)ùõøùêºùë§\delta(I,w) consists of non-marked states of Aùê¥A, i.e., Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚à©F=‚àÖùõøùêºùë§ùêπ\delta(I,w)\cap F=\emptyset. Then Œ¥‚Ä≤‚Äã(I‚à™{‚ô£},w‚ãÑ)=Œ¥‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚à™{‚ô£},‚ãÑ)={‚ô£}superscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùêº‚ô£limit-fromùë§‚ãÑsuperscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùõøùêºùë§‚ô£‚ãÑ‚ô£\delta^{\prime}(I\cup\{\clubsuit\},w\diamond)=\delta^{\prime}(\delta(I,w)\cup\{\clubsuit\},\diamond)=\{\clubsuit\}. Since Œ¥‚Äã(‚ô£,u)=‚ô£ùõø‚ô£ùë¢‚ô£\delta(\clubsuit,u)=\clubsuit for every word uùë¢u, we have that A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} is weakly (periodically) detectable.

If Aùê¥A is universal, we show that for every w‚àà(Œ£‚à™{‚ãÑ})‚àóùë§superscriptŒ£‚ãÑw\in(\Sigma\cup\{\diamond\})^{*} the set Œ¥‚Ä≤‚Äã(I‚à™{‚ô£},w)superscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùêº‚ô£ùë§\delta^{\prime}(I\cup\{\clubsuit\},w) has at least two elements, and therefore A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} is not weakly (periodically) detectable. If wùë§w does not contain ‚ãÑ‚ãÑ\diamond, then Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚à©F‚â†‚àÖùõøùêºùë§ùêπ\delta(I,w)\cap F\neq\emptyset. Then Œ¥‚Ä≤‚Äã(I‚à™{‚ô£},w)=Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚à™{‚ô£}superscriptùõø‚Ä≤ùêº‚ô£ùë§ùõøùêºùë§‚ô£\delta^{\prime}(I\cup\{\clubsuit\},w)=\delta(I,w)\cup\{\clubsuit\} and since ‚ô£‚àâŒ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚ô£ùõøùêºùë§\clubsuit\notin\delta(I,w), |Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)‚à™{‚ô£}|‚â•2ùõøùêºùë§‚ô£2|\delta(I,w)\cup\{\clubsuit\}|\geq 2. We now show that intractability holds even if the DESs are modeled as poDFAs over a very small alphabet.

Theorem 10.

Deciding weak (periodic) detectability of DESs modeled as poDFAs over the alphabet {0,1,‚ãÑ,a,b}01‚ãÑùëéùëè\{0,1,\diamond,a,b\} with aùëéa and bùëèb unobservable is PSpace-complete.

Proof 4.5.

If Aùê¥A is not universal, there is w‚àà{0,1}‚àó‚àñL‚Äã(A)ùë§superscript01ùêøùê¥w\in\{0,1\}^{*}\setminus L(A) and Œ¥‚Äã(I,w)ùõøùêºùë§\delta(I,w) contains no marked state of Aùê¥A. 5 Complexity of Deciding Strong Detectability

Shu and Lin¬†[11] designed a polynomial-time algorithm to decide strong (periodic) detectability, and hence the problem is in P. Is the problem P-complete or does it belong to NL? This question asks whether the problem can be efficiently parallelized (is in NL) or not (is P-complete)¬†[1]. We show that the problem is NL-complete and can thus be efficiently solved on a parallel computer.

Theorem 11.

Deciding whether a DES is strongly (periodically) detectable is NL-complete.

Proof 5.1.

For a DES Gùê∫G, Shu and Lin¬†[11] construct an NFA Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det} of polynomial size whose states are subsets of states of Gùê∫G of cardinality one or two (except for the initial state), such that Gùê∫G is strongly detectable if and only if (a) any state reachable from any loop in Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det} is of cardinality one; and strongly periodically detectable if and only if (b) all loops in Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det} include at least one state of cardinality one.

We prove the membership in NL by showing that checking that the conditions do not hold is in NL. Since NL is closed under complement¬†[5, 14], checking that the conditions are satisfied is also in NL.

To check that (a) is not satisfied, the NL algorithm guesses two states of Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det}, xùë•x and yùë¶y, where yùë¶y is of cardinality two, and verifies that yùë¶y is reachable from xùë•x, xùë•x is reachable from the initial state of Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det}, and xùë•x is in a cycle, i.e., xùë•x is reachable from xùë•x by a path having at least one transition.

To check that (b) is not satisfied, the NL algorithm guesses a state xùë•x of Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det} of cardinality two and verifies that xùë•x is reachable from the initial state of Gd‚Äãe‚Äãtsubscriptùê∫ùëëùëíùë°G_{det} and that xùë•x is in a cycle consisting only of states of cardinality two.

For more details how to check reachability in NL, the reader is referred to the literature¬†[8].

To show NL-hardness, we reduce the DAG non-reachability problem¬†[4]. Given a directed acyclic graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) and nodes s,t‚ààVùë†ùë°ùëâs,t\in V, it asks whether tùë°t is not reachable from sùë†s.

From Gùê∫G, we construct a DES A=(V‚à™{‚ô£},{a},Œ¥,s)ùê¥ùëâ‚ô£ùëéùõøùë†A=(V\cup\{\clubsuit\},\{a\},\delta,s), where ‚ô£‚àâV‚ô£ùëâ\clubsuit\notin V is a new state and aùëéa is an observable event. For every (p,r)‚ààEùëùùëüùê∏(p,r)\in E, we add the transition (p,a,r)ùëùùëéùëü(p,a,r) to Œ¥ùõø\delta, and for every p‚ààV‚àñ{t}ùëùùëâùë°p\in V\setminus\{t\}, we add the transition (p,a,‚ô£)ùëùùëé‚ô£(p,a,\clubsuit) to Œ¥ùõø\delta. Moreover, we add the self-loop transitions (‚ô£,a,‚ô£)‚ô£ùëé‚ô£(\clubsuit,a,\clubsuit) and (t,a,t)ùë°ùëéùë°(t,a,t) to Œ¥ùõø\delta. The construction is depicted in Fig.¬†8. Notice that Aùê¥A is deadlock-free and has no unobservable events. We now show that tùë°t is not reachable from sùë†s in the graph Gùê∫G if and only if the DES Aùê¥A is strongly (periodically) detectable.

If node tùë°t is not reachable from sùë†s in Gùê∫G, then, for every k‚â•|V|ùëòùëâk\geq|V|, Œ¥‚Äã(s,ak)={‚ô£}ùõøùë†superscriptùëéùëò‚ô£\delta(s,a^{k})=\{\clubsuit\}. Hence Aùê¥A is strongly (periodically) detectable.

If tùë°t is reachable from sùë†s, then, for every k‚â•|V|ùëòùëâk\geq|V|, Œ¥‚Äã(s,ak)={t,‚ô£}ùõøùë†superscriptùëéùëòùë°‚ô£\delta(s,a^{k})=\{t,\clubsuit\}. Hence Aùê¥A is not strongly (periodically) detectable.

We point out that using a unique event for every transition can show NL-hardness for DESs modeled as DFAs.

6 Conclusions

We studied the complexity of deciding detectability of discrete event systems modeled as finite automata and showed that deciding weak (periodic) detectability is intractable for all deadlock-free DESs. On the other hand, we showed that strong (periodic) detectability can be decided efficiently on a parallel computer.
